secondaryIdInfos.domain: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

identificationModule.officialTitle: Mobile Solutions for Neonatal Health (Mobile women’s and children’s health (WACh) NEO)

descriptionModule.briefSummary: This study evaluates the impact of an interactive (two-way) short messaging service (SMS) communication intervention, Mobile Solutions for Neonatal Health (Mobile WACh NEO), on neonatal mortality in Kenya. The intervention focuses on the perinatal period, sending automated tailored SMS messages to mothers during pregnancy and up to 6 weeks post partum. The messages utilize the Information-Motivation-Behaviour Skills framework to promote essential newborn care, identification of neonatal danger signs, care-seeking, and maternal social support. The study compares this intervention to standard care in a randomized controlled trial involving 5000 pregnant women.
descriptionModule.detailedDescription:
The Mobile WACh NEO study is a multisite, two-arm, 1:1 individually randomised, parallel group, superiority randomized controlled trial (RCT) conducted at six healthcare facilities in Kenya, including both rural and urban locations. The primary objective is to determine the effect of the interactive SMS messaging intervention on neonatal mortality, defined as death within the first 28 days of life.

Participants are pregnant women enrolled at 28–36 weeks estimated gestational age who have access to a mobile phone. They are randomised to either the intervention arm (two-way SMS) or the control arm (standard of care with no SMS). The intervention involves a series of automated SMS messages tailored to the participant's gestational age or time since delivery. The curriculum is grounded in the Information-Motivation-Behavioural Skills (IMB) model. Participants can also initiate SMS communication with study nurses for on-demand support. Specialized message tracks are available for high-risk groups, including first-time mothers, adolescents, women with elevated depression symptoms, and mothers of preterm or low birth weight infants.

Secondary objectives include determining the effect of the intervention on maternal implementation of essential newborn care (ENC) practices (such as breastfeeding, cord care, and thermal care), care-seeking behavior, and maternal psychosocial health (social support, self-efficacy, and depression). Data collection occurs at enrolment, 2 weeks post partum, and 6 weeks post partum through questionnaires and clinic record abstraction.

designInfo.interventionModelDescription: The Mobile WACh NEO study is a multisite, two-arm, 1:1 individually randomised, parallel group, superiority RCT comparing peripartum interactive two-way SMS to standard of care (no SMS) control.

maskingInfo.maskingDescription: Participants and study staff are unblinded to study arm. The principal investigator (PI) and coinvestigators are blinded to study findings until study close.

armGroups.label: Two-way SMS
armGroups.description: Participants receive the Mobile WACh NEO intervention, consisting of automated tailored SMS messages during pregnancy and up to 6 weeks post partum. Participants can also send SMS to the study nurse for on-demand remote support.

armGroups.label: Control
armGroups.description: Participants do not receive SMS messages from Mobile WACh NEO (no SMS). They receive standard antenatal care (ANC) and maternal and child health (MCH) clinical services.

interventions.name: Mobile WACh NEO
interventions.description: An interactive (two-way) short messaging service (SMS) communication intervention focused on the perinatal period. Messages employ the Information-Motivation-Behaviour Skills framework to promote maternal implementation of essential newborn care, identification of danger signs, and social support.

primaryOutcomes.description: Death within the first 28 days after live birth.

secondaryOutcomes.description: Neonatal mortality occurring in the first 7 days of life.
Proportion of mothers who initiate exclusive breast feeding in the first hour of life.
Proportion of mothers who delay bathing for at least 24 hours after birth.
Proportion of mothers who apply no substances to the umbilical cord.
Time to cessation of breast feeding.
Proportion of mothers of preterm or low birth weight neonates who provide KMC.

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Maternal knowledge of neonatal danger signs
secondaryOutcomes.description: Number of neonatal danger signs successfully named by the mother.
Proportion of women with elevated depression symptoms assessed by the Edinburgh Postnatal Depression Scale (EPDS).
Social support score assessed by the MOS Social Support Scale.
Self-efficacy score assessed by the Karitane Parenting Confidence Scale.
Appropriate care seeking for any instances of infant or maternal illness.

otherOutcomes.description: Determinants of SMS engagement and participants' experiences with the intervention assessed via in-depth interviews.

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:
- ≥14 years old
- Pregnant at 28–36 weeks estimated gestational age
- Enrolled in antenatal care at a study site
- Have daily access to a shared or personal mobile phone with a subscriber identity module on the Safaricom network
- Willing to receive SMS
- Plan to stay in the area for 5 months or greater
- Literacy is not required if a woman has access to a partner or trusted person who she is comfortable having read her the messages

Exclusion Criteria:
- Enrolled in another study
